context: [2] ATP is the main energy carrier that drives virtually all cellular processes. [3] Quiescent T cells rely mainly on the metabolism of glucose, amino acids, and fatty acids for ATP production, which depends on the TCA cycle and oxidative phosphorylation . [4] T cell stimulation induces a metabolic switch toward aerobic glycolysis, which allows rapidly dividing T cells to meet their extensive energetic and biosynthetic demands. [5] Because of the central role of glycolysis in proliferating T cells, mitochondrial ATP production has been considered to have a secondary, if any role in T cell activation . [6] However, recent evidence suggests that mitochondria may have a more profound role in T cell activation. [7] For example, mitochondria have been shown to accumulate at the immune synapse (IS) that T cells form with antigen-presenting cells (APC). [8] Mitochondria are thought to be necessary in order to regulate Ca2+ homeostasis and to generate reactive oxygen species that modulate signaling pathways downstream of the TCR/CD28 co-receptor .
